speed.title: Speed
speed.concept: Speed is the rate at which an object covers distance. It's about how fast you are going, regardless of direction.
speed.goal: Observe how a car moving a set distance over time has a measurable speed.

quiz.question: If a car travels 100 meters in 10 seconds, what is its speed?

velocity.title: Velocity
velocity.concept: Velocity is speed in a given direction. It's not just how fast, but also where you are going.
velocity.goal: Understand that velocity includes direction by watching a plane fly across the screen.

quiz.question: What makes velocity different from speed?

acceleration.title: Acceleration
acceleration.concept: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. You accelerate when you speed up, slow down, or change direction.
acceleration.goal: See acceleration in action as a rocket speeds up when it launches into the sky.

quiz.question: A rocket speeding up to go to the moon is an example of...?

gravity.title: Gravity
gravity.concept: Gravity is the invisible force that pulls objects toward each other. On Earth, it pulls everything down.
gravity.goal: Learn how gravity, launch angle, and power affect an object's curved path.

quiz.question: What is the force that pulls a thrown ball back to Earth?

energy.title: Energy
energy.concept: Energy transforms from Potential (stored) to Kinetic (motion). The total energy stays the same!
energy.goal: Visualize energy conservation on a roller coaster as it trades height for speed.

quiz.question: When a roller coaster is at the very top of a hill, it has the most...?

friction.title: Friction
friction.concept: Friction is a force that slows things down when surfaces rub together.
friction.goal: See how different surfaces (like ice or sandpaper) create more or less friction.

quiz.question: Which surface would have the MOST friction?

electricity.title: Electricity
electricity.concept: Electricity is the flow of electrons. For them to flow, they need a complete path called a circuit.
electricity.goal: Learn the parts of a simple circuit and how to connect them to light a bulb.

quiz.question: To light a bulb with a battery, you need a complete...?

magnetism.title: Magnetism
magnetism.concept: Magnets have two poles (North and South). Opposite poles attract, while like poles repel.
magnetism.goal: Use the forces of attraction and repulsion to move a ball through a maze.

quiz.question: If you bring two 'North' poles of a magnet together, they will...?

atoms.title: Atoms
atoms.definition: Atoms are the tiny, fundamental building blocks of everything! Like LEGO bricks for the universe, they make up all solids, liquids, and gases.
atoms.example: A single drop of water contains billions and billions of water molecules, and each molecule is made of hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

quiz.question: What are the three main particles inside an atom?

states_of_matter.title: States of Matter
states_of_matter.definition: Matter usually exists in one of three states: solid, liquid, or gas. The state depends on how much energy the atoms have and how tightly they are packed together.
states_of_matter.example: Ice (solid) melts into water (liquid), which can then be boiled to create steam (gas). It's all the same stuff, just in different states!

quiz.question: If you leave an ice cream cone in the sun, it turns from a solid into a...?

chemical_reactions.title: Chemical Reactions
chemical_reactions.definition: A chemical reaction is a process that transforms one set of chemical substances to another. It's like a recipe where you mix ingredients to create something new!
chemical_reactions.example: Baking a cake is a great example! You mix flour, sugar, and eggs (reactants), and after heating, you get a delicious cake (product).

quiz.question: What happens when you mix baking soda and vinegar?
options: It fizzes and creates a gas
quiz.answer: It fizzes and creates a gas

cells.title: Cells
cells.definition: Cells are the basic building blocks of all living things. Your body is made of trillions of them! They are like tiny rooms that perform all the jobs needed for life.
cells.example: Plant cells have a strong cell wall to give them structure, while animal cells are more flexible. Both have a nucleus, which is like the cell's brain.

quiz.question: What is the 'brain' or control center of the cell called?

photosynthesis.title: Photosynthesis
photosynthesis.definition: Photosynthesis is the amazing process where plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to create their own food (sugar) and release oxygen for us to breathe.
photosynthesis.example: A sunflower turning its face to the sun is soaking up energy to make its food. It's like a solar-powered chef!

quiz.question: What do plants release during photosynthesis that is essential for humans?

ecosystems.title: Ecosystems
ecosystems.definition: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms (like plants and animals) interacting with their physical environment (like the sun, soil, and water).
ecosystems.example: A coral reef is a vibrant ecosystem where fish, coral, and algae all depend on each other and the warm, salty water to survive.

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT an example of an ecosystem?

solar_system.title: The Solar System
solar_system.definition: Our solar system is made up of the Sun and everything that orbits around it, including planets, moons, asteroids, and comets. Earth is one of eight planets!
solar_system.example: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system, while Mercury is the smallest. They all travel in a predictable path, or orbit, around the Sun.

quiz.question: Which planet is famous for its beautiful rings?

stars.title: Stars
stars.definition: Stars are giant, luminous balls of hot gas (mostly hydrogen and helium) that produce their own light and heat through nuclear fusion. Our Sun is a star!
stars.example: At night, we see thousands of stars from Earth, but they are all incredibly far away. The closest star to us, besides the Sun, is Proxima Centauri.

quiz.question: What is the name of our closest star?

galaxies.title: Galaxies
galaxies.definition: A galaxy is a huge collection of gas, dust, and billions of stars and their solar systems, all held together by gravity. We live in the Milky Way galaxy.
galaxies.example: The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest major galaxy to our own Milky Way. One day, billions of years from now, they are expected to collide!

quiz.question: What is the name of the galaxy we live in?
